1.content:
Please Select your Race.

Kobolds
Kobolds are short, reptilian humanoids with cowardly and sadistic tendencies. Their scaly skin ranges from dark rusty brown to a rusty black color. They has glowing red eyes. Their tail is nonprehensile. Kobolds wear ragged clothing, favoring red and orange. A kobold is 2 to 2½ feet tall and weighs 35 to 45 pounds. Kobolds speak Draconic with a voice that sounds like that of a yapping dog.

Kobolds like to attack with overwhelming odds—at least two to one—or trickery; should the odds fall below this threshold, they usually flee. However, they attack gnomes on sight if their numbers are equal.

They begin a fight by slinging bullets, closing only when they can see that their foes have been weakened. Whenever they can, kobolds set up ambushes near trapped areas.

Kobolds are dazzled in bright sunlight or within the radius of a daylight spell.

Metallic Dragons
Metallic dragons make up the good branch of dragonkind, but they are every bit as aggressive as their evil cousins when threatened or challenged. They also tend to be covetous and proud.

Gem Dragons
Gem Dragons are neither good nor evil, but view the world in a neutral way. They tend to follow a path that benefits them most.

Chromatic Dragons
Chromatic dragons form the evil branch of dragonkind. They are aggressive, greedy, vain, and nasty.

Other
Half Dragons, and non-kobold/dragon races here

Likes: Shinies, Fiya, Shiny Koboldesses, Masta Flare!!!

Character Class:

Name: Klang of Berkberk Clan, AKA, 'Da Masta of Fiya' 'The hoarder of shinies' 'Da Knight of Inferno', 'Master Flare's #1 Minion!!'
Age: 17
Sex: M

Appearance: Standing at a mighty 2 foot 11, and tipping the scales at 43 pounds, he towers over most of his race, and his dragonblood makes him look, well, shinier than the average kobold. Yet to the eyes of most humanoids, he's a scrawny little thing, bright red in color, but by the Ancestors look at those wings!! Those wings!!


Biography: When Klang was born, with the rare trait of wings, he was immediately hailed as a prophet within his clan, an incarnation of dragonhood and combined with great natural abilities, was constantly told how he would lead the clan to new heights. He was taught the arts of sorcery, which Klang quickly proved adept at.

However, his clan was one day attacked by a band of adventurers, forcing them to flee. Deeply traumatized by the experience, Klang and his clan, drifted from city to city, usually belittled for being a kobolds, with none recognizing his greatness, having to endure humiliating circumstances such as begging, odd jobs and most recently as an exotic pets by a human slave trader. That circumstance did not last long, as the human slaver soon found himself being burned into a crisp after Klang crafted a nasty magic fire trap that involved pigs, booze and oil, but the satisfaction of murdering his slave master did not last long as Klang was then captured and now found himself slated for execution.

Klang found himself rescued by Master Flare, a young chromatic dragon looking to make a name for himself, and also seeking to gain a band of loyal servants. Klang, honored to be in the presence of a dragon pledged to do the chromatic dragon's bidding. Master Flare doesn't treat him or his clan overly well, seeing Klang as merely one of his many expendable minions, but Klang does not mind at all the poor treatment at all. So long as he gets to serve in the presence of a mighty dragon!!


Personality: Klang thinks very well of himself, spouting out constantly that he is a dragon reborn, as if he is the one that is 30 feet long and several tons, and wants everybody to know it, using by blowing out puffs of smoke into the air of random breaths of fire. This bragging belays a deep cowardice that he is not quite good enough, that he’s not really as dragon, and doubt constantly creeps into his kobold mind. Yet he doesn’t hate people really, because well its never a good idea to antagonize your meat shields. Klang also likes shinies, thinking that hoarding shinies will make him more like a dragon, and he is also a notorious cheapskate. He would burn his own mother for a copper piece. Lastly, Klang likes fire, very, very, very much.

With his traveling companions and non-kobolds or draconic speakers, Klang can be obnoxious at times, perhaps fitting into a stereotype of kobolds being 'nasty little buggers'. His favorite words are 'Berk', 'Stronk', 'Fiya' and 'Shiny'.

Yet at the same time, Klang actually has another more formal personality, which he shows to others of his kind. Sorcerers are thought of highly in kobold society, and as such takes great efforts to act in a very polite, and respectful manner. He very much thinks himself as though he is a paragon of kobold society, ever seeking to push the fate of his people forward and fighting selflessly on their behalf, and has a very refined taste for koboldesses. Those who would know Klang as an obnoxious bugger would be shocked at the contrasting behavior Klang comports himself with others of his kind.

Klang is very subservient in the presence of his master, Flare the Chromatic Fire Dragon, and sees the dragon with a combination of fear and awe. The reason he hasn't died yet is because Klang is pretty adept at telling Master Flare the things he likes to hear and assuaging the dragon's ego, along with the fact that the kobold amuses him.

Now, what is Klang doing at this very moment?

11113.content:
The hot springs in the center of the cave system acted as a sort of social gathering place for the kobold clan. Klang had his own spot in the hotsprings, a small rock outcropping near the edge of the waters. It was not a natural formation, instead built by the clan for Klang. It had a pathway of rocks that came to the outcropping, to allow Klang to reach it without getting wet, if he so chose. It had a simple throne made out of the nearby stones to allow him to retain a command presence if needed. Next to the throne was a large flat area, perfect for laying down and drying off. The outcropping had a small inlet in it, a private pool where Klang could relax. He was in this pool, watching over the social activities of the kobolds.. HIS kobolds.

On the shore of the springs, tables were set up, taken from various raids, and different bottles of drink. The kobolds had done enough work in human lands to recognize the benefit of a well stocked bar. In here, everyone was off duty, and there was no rank, no prestige, except for Klang, or perhaps Flare if he had ever decided to come in and mingle with the masses.

On each arm, in the pool with him were two female kobolds, no one in particular, just had been in the right place at the right time. They were each taking turns rubbing a cloth against his scales and wings.

Off on her own was another kobold, a blue scaled by the name of Frill. Not that the clan had an issue with Frill, she was one of theirs.. but Frill always seemed to do her own thing.

111132.content:
"Ah... that is very nice pretty ones..." said Klang in his smooth draconic, feeling the koboldesses stretch and massage his wings. His hands were wrapped around their smooth bodies, and his claw tips explored one of their tails.

"Bartender!! If you would be so kind, a drink for myself and the two young koboldesses," said Klang. He snapped his fingers to signal what he wanted. Before long, the bartender had summoned three glasses full of beer. With both of his arms already occupied by the two koboldesses, Klang summoned a few mage hands to deftly take the glasses and serve them to himself and his koboldesses. The drink was of moderate strength, enough to give him a nice buzz, but not to the point where he would take leave of his senses.

Before long, one thing led to another and Klang found himself thoroughly enjoying his time with the shiny koboldesses in the jacuzzi. Klang had proven himself the strongest of the kobolds, and thus felt entitled to have any female that he chose, and that he was blessed by the Ancestors indeed that such pretty ones had come by. As chieftain of the clan, he had already sired a decent number of eggs, and with the way that Klang was going at it with the koboldesses, it would seem that it was number that he was keen on seeing grow. At the end of it, Klang reclined at the edge of the bath with a crooked smile on his pointed jaw, the two females laid contently at his side, their tongues lolling out in a wondrous daze.

It was only then that Klang noticed the other blue female. She was named Frill wasn't she? Klang had tried seducing her before, but she had never been interested, perhaps given that she liked spending her time with one of the guards.

Klang stepped out of the Jacuzzi, making himself decent before facing Frill.

"Ah yes... is there something I may do for you?" asked Klang.

1111321.content:
"Master Flare wishes to speak with you..." said Frill.

Klang's earlier haze instantly stiffened into fearful focus. "He does? Did he say what he wants from me?"

All of the kobold clans that paid fealty to Flare both worshipped and feared the large red dragon, very much like God of the Old Testament. To a kobolds, who already had a natural, inbuilt subservience to dragonkind, Flare was very much like a force of nature; powerful and unshakable. When Master Flare called a kobold over, they were expected to drop everything and address him. It didn't matter if they were on a great quest, or seeing the birth of their hatchling, or currently having sex; if you didn't answer his summons, you ended up as literal dragon food.

"No, I am afraid that he did not specify..." answered Frill.

Klang let out a gulp.

"Then I shall go attend to him immediately..."

The other kobolds suddenly gave him sympathetic looks, or as if he was about to walk to his own funeral.

Klang exited the cave system of the Berkberk Clan, and took the long trek up the great mountain, which was quite cold, to the lair where Master Flare dwelled, which was naturally at the top of that mountain. As he climbed, a sense of fear grew within the little kobold. Had Klang not worshipped Master Flare properly? Surely, he had done everything he could to ensure that every member of his clan knew that he was Master!! Klang was near catatonic as all the various scenarios of how he could have conceivably displeased Master Flare as he went inside.

Master Flare oftentimes took the form of a kobold, usually to personally observe the goings on of the kobold clan, but it was only during important tasks, he made sure that he was in his full draconic form. Whenever he was in draconic form, Flare wanted to make it crystal clear just who the Master truly was, and regardless of how much power Klang had amassed as chieftain of the Berkberk Clan, he was still a kobold and a servant, while he was a true dragon. The mere sight of the huge red dragon in his true form was both awe inspiring and fearsome to behold, leaving Klang's knees weak. He sat upon a huge nest of gold coins and treasure; the sight of it left his covetous senses mingling. Yet woe be any kobold who took even a coin of Master Flare's wealth. They tended to end up in his belly.

To Klang's dismay but not his surprise, Master Flare looked most displeased indeed.

"It is about time you have shown up to face your master. If you had been any slower, then I might have been forced to eat you whole!!" snapped Flare in common.

"Berk!!" chirped Klang with fright. The mere force that he spoke with nearly knocked the little kobold off his feet, and Flare relished in seeing Klang's fearful reaction.

"Please Masta Flare!! Good, glorious Masta!! Please no eat Klang!" he bowed down. Common tongue was not Klang's first language, yet when Master Flare spoke in common, he expected to be addressed in that language and with sufficient subservience as well. Flare also seemed to know of Klang's trouble with common, as Klang tended to talk to him much more subserviently than Klang would have had he been allowed to speak in his elegant draconic.

"What cans Klang do fors Masta Flare to please him!!" said Klang in a trembling voice. Flare, being a relatively young red dragon, was prone to sudden mood swings and bursts of anger, which meant that kobold chieftains had shorter than usual tenures as leaders of their respective clans. If Klang did not demonstrate what Flare deemed to be adequate subservience, he might decide to eat Klang. By the Ancestors, even if Klang did demonstrate adequate subservient, Flare might decide to eat him anyways just for the heck of it and there was nothing Klang would be able to do about it.

Flare's eyes narrowed menacingly. "The humans have slighted me..."

"Da humans? But... but wes trade with dem! Dey be peaceful..." chirped Klang, perplexed.

Flare's nostrils billowed with smoke and out a short roar, "You dare question me in this?"

"Beeerrrrkkk!!" chirped Klang, going bug-eyed his body stiffening in fright, "Of course no Masta Flare!! Ehehe... Dose nasty, nasty humans!! Dey speaks most terrible things of Masta Flare!! Dey shoulds be punished, mosts terribly!!"

Flare seemed contented that he had gotten his way, as he always did of course.

"I am glad that you have seen reason, my little servant," said Master Flare.

"You see, the human kingdom of Vertigard has failed to deliver a maiden to me at the appropriate time. My only interpretation of this is that its king has begun to think that he can defy me. He needs to be shown that he is mistaken to think this," said Flare. "He shall pay!!"

Klang blinked. Was Master Flare crazy, going to war with an entire human kingdom?

"But Masta Flare!! We nos have da forces to take ova and destroy da Kingdom!! He hire adventurers, and dey bes nothing but trouble!!"

Flare's eyes went wide again, burning with fire, and Klang feared that he might have signed his own death warrant.

"Do you dare have any other suggestion then?"

Klang wondered if he should talk. Well, if he was already dead anyhow, what was the harm in it?

"Umm... wes can infiltrate da Kingdom!! Deys only no deliver a maiden yes? So wes sneak into da capital city ands steals dere princess and deliver her to Master Flare!! When we no have to destroy da kingdom and dey only bes intimidated, den you still be ables to extract manys, manys more shinies from dem!! So, Masta Flare end up with even bigger horde den before!!" he chirped, his body trembling.

Please don't eat me, please don't eat me...

Flare rumbled. "Yes, I believe I like that plan valued minion..."

"You dos?" asked Klang with a small voice.

"Now that I think about it, simply flying over the capital city and razing it to the ground might be unprofitable. Taking the King's daughter and forcing the king to either pay a huge ransom to get her back, or better yet if he refuses I'd get a prime opportunity to ravage her; it would be a far more potent demonstration of my virility I must say. Either way, the King of Vertigard would be cowed to the point where they would continue to pay tribute to me. I'm glad I thought of it..."

"Yes!!" nodded Klang. "Yous truly a brilliant, brilliant Masta!!"

"Indeed I am," said Flare, "Since you are such a valued minion..."

Klang purred like the cat on an evil mastermind's lap.

"I am assigning you and your best team of kobolds to make sure that the scheme succeeds. Infiltrate into the capital city of Vertigard, kidnap the princess, and bring her to me alive!! Failure will not be tolerated, and will see the liquidation of your entire clan if you fail. However, if you succeed, my favor toward you and your clan will increase,"

"Oh Master!! Good Master!!" bowed Klang. "Thank you for gibbing Klang da privilege of servings you!! Klang will not fails you!! He bring you much glory and shinies!! All hail Masta Flare!!"

"Good!! Now get going!!" he bellowed.

Klang made his way out of the room, letting out a sigh of relief. Every time he went into Master Flare's chamber, he went in there half-expecting his own death, but in its place he had given him an even greater task.
1111321.title: I serve you Masta Flare!!

11113211.content:
Awaiting outside of Flares cavern was Frill. Klang knew that Frill had not been in direct service to Master Flare too long, having been doing odd jobs for the clan before, though she had made a name for herself for being stubborn and insubordinate to her superiors. Why Flare chose this one to be his personal assistant was something only Flare knew, but Klang suspected it had a lot to do with Frill's own draconic blood.

"Master Flare said he would have a task for you, and I was to assist you in it, Chief."

She was looking forward to a bit of adventure, not having ever been too content sitting in the caves all day long. Frill's sire was a blue half dragon that had sought refuge in the caverns, one of the few times Flare had shown generosity, even allowed him to take his pick of the females to keep him comfortable for the night. Of course, that generosity did come with a price, and Frill was the result. Though only a quarter dragon, Frill showed an intelligence that would be equalled to Klang, unlike most kobolds. Why Flare was cultivating kobolds with dragons blood in them was another unknown question, one that Klang had no intent of ever asking.

He looked to Frill with a grin. "Its good to know that Master Flare intended the entire time to send me on a task. This job is a kidnapping, taking the King of Vertigard's daughter because they stopped with tributes. We will need two others. Do you have suggestions?"

Frill thought on that as her tail twitched back and forth. "My clutchmate, Skiir. He good with a blade and can be trusted to watch our back"

Klang nodded. "Skiir.. yes I know him, the one that always seems to be watching you when he doesn't think anyone is looking?"

Frill tried to hide her amusement at that. "Skiir has it in his mind to flirt with me every time he gets, wanting a chance to fill me with a clutch no doubt. I am just not interested in him that way. He is a good friend, and a good protector." She thinks some more. "Actually, we should find the shamans and see if they can recommend anyone as well. It could not hurt to have a healer present.
11113211.title: Gather up a team of kobolds and do Master Flare...

choices: Kirill, a female cleric, more light armor and magic based
Straha, a male cleric, more tanky frontline type
111132112.content:
Oh... Frill wasn't interested in that way? Klang had had enough experience with kobolds to know that perhaps she was not as uninterested as she seemed to believe. During the long road of travel, it was likely that something would happen between those two. Yes, she and Skiir would do quite nicely together, not only romance wise but also combat.

Klang had seen Frill at her craft. She was a quick and dexterous fighter who was a whiz with daggers and hand crossbows, craft all manners of nasty traps and could pick any lock and most of all was intelligent. Her clutchmate Skiir was the stronger of the two, a powerfully adept swordsman who had the strength of the much larger humanoid species.

He wouldn't have to worry about those two.

However, their little group would need a healer, and Klang knew just where to find one.

He headed off to the clan's local temple of Kurtulmak, down a series of dark, winding passageways. At every periodic point, he would seemingly randomly move to the side, or duck and the like; he knew that should any pesky adventurers attempt to infiltrate this holy place, they would be hit by all sorts of traps.

The entrance of the temple of Kurtulmak was a long corridor, leading to a grand hallway that finished with a statue of Kurtulmak. While Klang was a worshipper of Astilabor, the goddess of wealth and hordes, he nonetheless held a deep respect for the faith of Kurtulmak, being the patron god of kobolds.

"Hello Chieftain Klang," said the head priest, an old kobold named Kharaman.

"I greet you my old teacher," said Klang with a bow. "It is good to see that you are still well..."

Kharaman had been the one who had been Klang's instructor when Klang had been growing up from a hatchling, who had taught him discipline, his knowledge in Draconic and lastly his abilities. Klang owed the old wyrm a lot, and he would dare say that without his guidance, he probably would have ended up in Master Flare's belly quite a long time ago. While he moved on a cane nowadays, he still moved with a steady gait, and nobody in the clan was wiser. Even now, he served as an elder advisor of sorts, to help him make decisions for the best of the Berkberk Clan and how he should approach Master Flare.

"Indeed," he replied, "It is a boon to see you as well, my old apprentice. What brings you around?"

"First, to offer my prayers of course," said Klang. "But secondly, there is a task of great importance. Master Flare has called upon me personally to lead an expedition to obtain tribute from the Kingdom of Vertigern, specifically in the form of the king's daughter. The quest to travel to their capital city, gain entry, capture her and get back safely will be a long and arduous one, and I would have need of the services of a user of divine magic."

"Ah... that's quite a quest indeed. I would recommend the temple's most talented prodigy, and the task you have in mind would be ideal for achieving fame..."

"As for the kobold I have in mind, that would be..."
111132112.title: The old master

choices: Look for one more member of the expedition
Reunite with Frill and Skirr and take off straight away
1111321121.content:
"Kirill, our golden prodigy..."

Klang blinked, "Golden prodigy?"

His confusion did not last long, as a gold scaled koboldess with wings came forward. Wait a second, a kobold with a metallic dragon ancestry?

"You called Master Kharaman?" said the gold koboldess, gliding into the room.

"Indeed Kirill..."

"What is this? A kobold with metallic ancestry?" said Klang skeptically. Normally, no kobolds with any ancestry in metallic were ever allowed in, but perhaps he had thought wrong. Kirill gave Klang a sharp look, perhaps not even caring she was addressing the leader of the entire clan.

"Yes she indeed does Chieftain Klang, and as I told you, she is our most talented prodigy in divine magic. I trust that you will be able to make use of her in the quest."

"I believe that I would," said Klang, trusting his old instructor's judgment in this. He was a bit miffed that he had not been informed of the fact that his clan had taken in a metallic descended kobold; even with there being a large number of kobolds in his clan, he figured that he would have heard of such a thing happening. Maybe Kharaman had decided to pull a fast one over Klang to keep his former apprentice on his heels?

"Though I am curious, Kirill," said Klang, "How you managed to be raised by Master Kharaman. Being the chieftain, one would think I would hear of all the kobolds in my clan, or at the very least exceptional ones such as yourself...."

"I was told that my birth mother lost my egg during an adventurer attack, and that I was found by Master Kharaman and raised to be a proper devotee to Kurtulmak," she shared. Klang could tell from her tone that such a vague explanation did not seem to satisfy the young koboldess and did not believe that to be the entire story for a second, who clearly wanted to know more. If that was the story that Kharaman had brought her up with, then Klang would have been suspicious that he had not told the whole truth either.

How did those with metallic ancestry end up siring a kobold that ended up in a clan with near total Chromatic? Whatever that answer was, Klang decided not to press the point for the time being.

"Yet the circumstances of my birth are irrelevant. I am to prove to the chieftain, to Kurtulmak and to Master Flare that I am a worthy divine cleric. I hope that you can provide that opportunity chieftain Klang for me to demonstrate my talents," said Kirill confidently.

Klang couldn't help but flash a half smile. So, she was one of those prodigies who thought she could do anything? Well, Klang had not been too much different himself, so he could relate to that. He also wondered if her metallic heritage made Kirill even more than usual to demonstrate her abilities and overcome whatever prejudices she might have faced.

"In fact, that is exactly why I have come Kirill," said Klang. He explained the mission that Master Flare had given to him, along with the other kobolds that they would be working with thus far.

"I suppose that would be a worthwhile means for me to finally display my prodigious talents properly. So, when those two end up stumbling into traps, you want me to bail them out correct?" she said with a huff.

"In a sense, but don't be afraid to ask them for help either, though those two will need to take some time to get used to you..." said Klang.

"I have no doubts of your abilities, but how prepared are you truly? For instance, how well can you speak common?"

Kirill puffed herself up, "I's speaks it wells enough," she squeaked. "Fars superiors to da others in da klan! With alls due respect of course chieftain!" she insisted.

Well, that actually wasn't any worse than Klang's common tongue. However, she would need to work on that attitude a bit. She was quite a looker he had to admit. Maybe a good, hard fuck to pop her cherry would be effective. Despite her arrogance, Kirill was indeed a supremely talented magic user, and you know... perhaps a pairing between an arcane caster such as himself and a pretty female like that would be an interesting breeding experiment. Yet maybe that was just Klang's lust for shiny kobold's speaking.

More likely the realities on the road would shape her up a bit.

"Well, as you can tell Chieftain Klang," said Kharaman, "You'll have quite the clawful with this little firecracker! Yet I am confident that she will shape up just fine..."

"Thank you chieftain," answered Klang, in a voice where he wasn't sure if he wasn't being facetious or not.

"So, when are we heading off?" snapped Kirill.

"Patience, we still need to gather up all the necessary gear for the quest, and whether or not we want to take anybody else..."
1111321121.title: Kirill, the golden prodigy

choices: Choose Skiir to be the kidnapper
Choose Kirill to be the kidnapper
Klang's own head is at risk here. Try a different solution
11113211212.content:
Klang and Kirill headed back to to the caverns where Skiir and Frill were busy packing their items. Among them were various hides prepared for travel. Frill glanced back as Klang entered with the golden kobold.

"Just in time... I was supposed to be handling the trade of hides with the nearby town, but was .. interrupted by Master Flare offering me a job." Skiir looked as if he was about to say something about that, but clamped his maw shut as Frill gave him a glare. There was obviously more to the story there. "Apparently they did not find a replacement for me, so the trade still has to be done. It will give us an excuse to be in the lands, and a trade permit in case the authorities stop us."

Skiir nodded at that. "Humans like their rules, we play by them, they mostly leave us alone. And with some coin from the trade, we can make sure we got coin to spend around when we get to the capitol. We need to ensure we got witnesses say that we not do kidnapping. Means that whoever taking the princess cant be seen with us."

Frill nodded. "I need to be one seen because permit is made to me, and two for guards is allowed. So one who be doing actual kidnapping will be spending entire trip in hidden compartment in trunk." She motioned to a rather large, uncomfortable looking, old wooden trunk.

Skiir hesitated. "Chief... choice is yours on how you want it done." It was clear he wasnt too keen about being put in the box, though Klang couldn't blame him. The possibilities ended up being down to three, each with their own advantages and disadvantages. Klang knew he could kidnap the Princess easy enough as long as she was caught unaware, but the idea of being in the box for at least 3 days sounded quite uncomfortable. Kirill was an unknown, and though claimed to be a follower of Kurtulmak, could be a trick. Then again, the golden scales would allow her to get closer to the target and trick the princess. Skiir would be another good option, as he could probably fight off two or three humans by himself. But Skiir tended to be a blunt force type creature, very little finesse, so would be hard for him to sneak to where he needed to go. However, if Skiir did go into the box, it meant Klang would be spending the trip in the private company of two quite lovely koboldess'.

111132112123.content:
"Well..." chirped Kirill, folding her arms, "I am not spending time in a box under any circumstances!! Its not happening!"

Frill let out a huff. "You afraid that you'll ruffle your wings shiny?" she sniffed.

"Of course!" she insisted, fluttering them couple of times, "My wings have to be in optimal condition for my spells to function properly!!"

"Come on koboldesses," said Klang. "No need to fight over it..."

The two females glared at each other; it seemed fairly clear that the personalities of those two clashed. Personally, Klang thought it was quite cute; in his mind he could envision them snuggling together and...

Focus Klang!!

"I... can do so if required," continued Skiir required, though he too was reluctant with the plan.

"I admire your spirit of volunteerism," said Klang, "But you're not exactly our best at stealth..."

"You know Frill," said Klang, "Frankly if we were going with the box plan, you, given your skill and dexterity, would actually be most suited for this."

Frill let out a squeak of surprise, as if she'd been found out.

"Yet at the same time, you already have a deal lined up and have to be seen by the merchant guilds."

It would seem that nobody, then, wanted to be stuck inside the box. Klang had to think up a different solution to this.

"Now, I might not have as much experience in trading with the humans as you do Frill, but surely, they would have checkpoints, and they would want to ask what is inside the box. If they open it up and find us inside, they'll suspect that something is up, and the game would be up. I do have an alternate plan in how we might be able to get away with this; we just need to look at it in another manner. We need not limit ourselves simply for respect to the humans rules; when we can utilize them to our advantage..."

"For one, I can craft a number of fake passes with good enough signatures, and furthermore, don't underestimate what magic can achieve to ensure we can escape suspicion. For example,"

Klang snapped his finger, and with a simple prestidigitation spell, the normally red kobold was suddenly a platinum scaled.

"Humans put quite a lot on color coding you see, and for the vast majority of humans, they will see me as a kobold of platinum origin and thus automatically assume me to be friendly to humans," said Klang. "Most humans can hardly differentiate between us aside from color, and if they put up notices for us, why, with another prestidigitation spell I can change my color scheme again..."

"That could work I guess; saves one of us from having to spend three days in a box," said Skiir, "But if its such a simple spell, wouldn't it be able to be seen through easily by anybody with rudimentary knowledge of magic?"

"I am still concerned if there are paladins in the city..."

"Ah, once again, my magic would be able to come in use," said Kirill with her trilling, high pitched voice, "I can ensure that they end up detecting the alignment they want to see from us. With the divine blessing from Kurtulmak, he shall certainly see us through!"

Frill rolled her eyes at the insufferable gold koboldess. Were all clerics this arrogant, or was it just this gold girl in particular?

"If the need is most acute, I would be able to turn somebody invisible or polymorph them into a humanoid, but unless something truly unexpected happens, we shouldn't need to worry too much until we get into the capital."

"Obviously, such methods are not fool proof, as those tutored in the arcane or divine magics would be able to see through an illusion, but it should be able to enable us to travel through these lands unmolested," said Klang.

"There is no reason we cannot complete the previous trade we had set up," said Klang. "So lets stop by there first. We can get a few rumors about what is going on, get some extra coins and maybe even buy a few goods ourselves..."

"Once we're in the capital city, we also might look about establishing some contacts; perhaps some non-Bahamut worshipping Dragonborns, local thieves, political rivals etc, who might have an interest in pursuing a conflict with the current ruler of Vertigern. The better we can divide the humans in their city, the easier it is for us to get off with our princess..."
111132112123.title: Another solution

1111321121231.content:
The arrival to the town of Miravale was without incident. Miravale was a smaller town and thus did not have a standing guard force. They had their militia of course, but the general protection of the area actually was done by the kobolds. It was a symbiotic relationship; The kobolds maintained the security of the roads, in exchange the town allowed itself to be used as a trade hub. This has proven to be quite beneficial to Miravale as well. Its reputation had grown to the point other non human races would come to the town to trade. Miravale even had a yearly festival where races that normally did not interact, used the city as a neutral ground for trade and negotiations.

This festival was 6 months away still, however... meaning that most likely the only things they would run into is kobolds who have chosen to work in the city, humans, and maybe a few other individuals who made the place home.

Frill explained this to everyone, more for Skiir and Kirill's purpose than Klangs. Lord Flare did not demand tribute from this town, provided it remained friendly to his kobold clan. Apparently the profits from the trading was enough, plus it meant they weren't hunted everytime they turned around.

The leader of the town was a known sympathiser to the kobolds, and would provide protection and an alibi if needed... after all, he profits quite well by skimming the taxes.

A temple to Kurtulmak existed in the town as well, though hidden from normal view in the underground of the town. There was a passage that linked to the kobold caves, though seldom used unless someone needed to escape from the town.

The General Store was where they needed to go to trade the hides, and the price had already be pre-determined. There should be no need for haggling.

The tavern accommodated all tastes, and on rare occasion offered long pork for any who knew to ask, usually some unfortunate soul sentenced to death by the local constabulary.

A orcish blacksmith lived in the town, offering fine orcish armor and weapons, for a price. He usually does work by request or consignment and usually doesnt have a large stock on hand.

The Constable worked for the crown, but a few crowns his way has ensured that has looked the other way during some shady deals in the past.
1111321121231.title: Arriving at the first town

choices: Tell the mayor about Klang's mission
Keep things as they are.. Klang has said enough
11113211212311.content:
Klang decided to go visit the Mayor of Miravale..."

A short, portly human, (well, he still towered over Klang) was present to greet him.

"Oh... if it isn't chieftain Klang," said the Mayor.

"Hellos Mayor Haldric," said Klang in his broken common. The Mayor did not speak Draconic particularly well, so Klang had to speak in common.

"What bes the goings on in da humans capital? Masta Flare send us on special mission dere, and be concern but what going through da mind of King Theudebert...." said Klang.

"Yes... yes..." said the Mayor.

"Well you see, word is that the King's got a whole different set of advisors as of late, and been levying tariffs on any non-human groups in the kingdom. He's facing pressure from all sorts of church organizations, Templars and other goody two types not to compromise with 'evil', as he puts it, and have been distributin all sorts of coin to nobles, merchants, clerics and anybody who'd listen to take a harder stance. I'd already seen a number of those adventuring types stop by; they haven't caused trouble yet, but if they're being paid by the ones advising the king, I reckon they'd start causin trouble. Also heard that he's trying to marry off his daughter to one of these Crusading type nobles as well, and that they're workin on a betrothal, and if it happens he might try and organize an army to 'purify the land of evil'; you know how those types are."

"Now then, if that happens, big ol' Flare is gonna come swoopin' down on the capital which will be good for nobody, not me, not you and not for the kingdom," said Haldric. "It would be all out war..."

"Klang see... It explain why da King no longer be gibbing tribute to Flare, because he think dat dese Templars be telling him dat wes evil," said Klang.

By what he was hearing from Theudebert, it would seem that dealing with some of those troublesome nobles and Templars would do more to help restore the status quo, then taking the more provocative move of capturing the princess. However, Master Flare had explicitly ordered the princesses captured, and disobeying Master Flare was a big no-no.

It was a decision that Klang would have to make; but he still needed to know more. Klang also wondered if he should reveal the full scope of the mission to Theudebert, who was sympathetic to the kobolds and could lend tangible support in terms of goods and manpower. Sympathetic, of course, did not necessarily mean that he would be disloyal to the crown.
11113211212311.title: The Mayor

choices: Continue from Frill's Point of View
111132112123112.content:
Human sailors themselves had an expression... Loose lips sank ships. And in this instance, it would probably kill kobolds too. Klang decided not to mention more to Theudebert. After all, the only thing that the Mayor was loyal to was gold, and the kings men could most likely offer more than enough for him to betray them.

Klang gave a nod. "We finish then trade in city, then go back to caves, report to Master Flare what you say." Not that they had any intent to go back to the caves, but the human didn't need to know that. "Master Flare want to know if Miravale continue to support?"

Theudebert gave a nod. "Oh yes of course! What the Templars do is the kings business, but as long as I am mayor here, your kind will always be welcomed! And if there is anything on the side you need, I can see what I can do. Nothing wrong with being friendly with the kobold chieftain as well.

Klang gave a nod and thought. Frill had quietly stepped away, and wasn't in eyeshot, most likely performing her own investigation. Klang was now just keeping the human busy. "Not wrong to be friendly to Klang at all! As long as you not get Klang in trouble with Master Flare yes?" He looked to Theudebert curiously. "What is it you got that Klang might want?"
111132112123112.title: Keep things as they are.. Klang has said enough

choices: Continue with Klang and Magical items
Follow Kirill to the temple of Kurtulmak
Follow Frill and Skiir to check out tavern
1111321121231121.content:
Klang was one that enjoyed a few magical items in his collection... that and shiny coins made him feel that he had a bit of a hoard, and closer to being a dragon. Most of the equipment the clan used was communal, but being the chief allowed some privileges He glanced over to see Frill returning, apparently completed her task in casing the mayors house. A slight shake of her head told him what he needed to know.. the house was clean, and there was no evidence the mayor was secretly supporting the Templars.

Klang gave a wide grin. "Klang think perhaps some potions might be helpful, got small list if you able to help, in exchange for kobold gratitude.

He glanced over to the others who were gathered and spoke in draconic once more. "Enjoy the town, but meet at gate by nightfall. We leave when moon rises. Keep ears open for any important information"

He turned back to Theudebert and grinned. "Oh and any pretty magic items Klang might find good to use, yes?"
1111321121231121.title: Magical Potions or items

11113211212311212.content:
"Chieftain Klang has decided to speak with the mayor of the town. I don't trust that mayor, and I was hoping that a follower of Kurtulmak, could tell me what's really going on in town..."

"Yes, well... I never trusted Theudebert either," said Hissa. "He seems to be trying to play both sides, trying to appease Flare but at the same time catering to the King he serves. Its a situation that can't last for him, as I think sooner rather than later with the human king's new laws he might be pressured into adopting the new laws."

"So, what would you want me to do?" asked Kirill.

"I have a series of sigils here that I've been working on. There's a small number of temples to Kurtulmak on a number of villages on the way to the capital, so I need you to hand one to each of the priests there so we can stay in communication with each other, get an advanced warning in case the humans try to organize an adventuring party against our kind," she informed, marking down each of the locations of the shrines on her map.

"It shall be done Mother Hissa!!" said Kirill.

"Good! Now, there is one other matter that I would wish your help in. Earlier today, we caught an unfortunate gnome who was poking around the wrong places in town..." explained Hissa.

"Ooooo.... are we going to sacrifice him?" asked Kirill excitedly. Kurtulmak espoused a hatred of gnomes for what Garl Glittergold had done to his lair, and since then there had existed a pathological hatred toward their wretched kind.

1152.content:
Frill moved quietly within the dark confines of the egg room, ensuring the temperature of each egg was exactly what it should be. Colder than what was needed to hatch, kobolds could keep eggs viable indefinitely, letting them hatch only when they needed a surge of new members. They have been at peace for a while, but peace always came with a price. They had hunters out of the clan looking for food and treasure outside the borders, to trade with the humans that lived nearby. As they were a source of trade, the human authorities have no seen a need to take them out. Part of their deal in this was to keep their numbers "manegable".

She didn't have a position in the clan, other than a member, and as such followed the commands of the guards themselves. The guards answered to a captain, who answered directly to the leader.

"So this is where you been hiding." The voice, draconic in language, was from one of the guards. If a human heard them talk, it would be like a bunch of yapping dogs, but the kobolds language was much richer than that, each yap could have its own meaning and actually expand the draconic language itself. Frill glanced back. "I am where you had sent me." She inspected the last egg before moving to the guard. "Now, what is it you want this time?" She spoke a bit testily, as THIS guard seemed to always seek her out for rather dull assignments.

The guard smirked. "Now Frill, you can at least address me by name..."
1152.title: Frill, Female Kobold Clan Member

choices: Take offer of going to the Human Town. Frill will certainly need a bath first
Take food to the hunters. It will be a 2 day round trip.
Take the rest of the day off and see what Skiir has planned
11521.content:
Frills voice softened slightly. "Skiir, you can be infuriating at times. You are lucky I like you" She shook her head. "What other tasks has the Captain assigned you to give out?"

Skiir gave a toothy grin as his tail swayed. He enjoyed picking on Frill, she was a clutchmate, as close to a sister as kobolds ever get. "I got a few tasks left that I am sure you would excel at doing" He looked her up and down before giving a grin again. "Of course we can always both just leave the duties for someone else and go sneak off for a swim, you are filthy."

She rolled her eyes a bit at his attempts at flirting. "And I guess you think Ill let you clean me is that it? Not to mention we both be in trouble if found missing our duties. What tasks do we have?"

He gave an almost disappointed pout. Skiir had been trying to get her somewhere alone for a while, and she knew why. Half the fun was teasing him along. "Fine. We need someone to go to the human town with a load of hide we trading. No need to bring back goods, this is on credit. Just get receipt. Or take food to hunters near border. They expecting delivery." His eyes twinkled micheviously. "Still say you need bath first, especially if going to human town."
11521.title: His name was Skiir, and he and Frill were part ...

choices: Skiir continues to scrub down Frill
Frill tells Skiir she can bathe herself
115211.content:
Frill gives him a glance, then sighs, almost as if it was a burden. "Human town then, I have wanted to visit one." She headed off to where the public baths were at. Skiir followed close behind.

"You will have a change of clothes for the town. We try to make it appear Kobolds are more than just the crazed beasts the humans think we are."

She gave a grin at that and swatted him once with her tail "But I LIKE being a crazed beast" She gave a laugh at that, as well as his attempt to grab her tail. Soon, they reached the baths, and at the moment, there was none there. Stripping off the simple red and orange cloth she wore, she let herself slip into the warm water. Letting out a hiss of pleasure, she murred to herself. The baths were warmed by an underwater spring, and as such made this bath a popular meeting place after work was done. Behind her, she could hear Skiir removing his armor and placing it neatly on some nearby rocks.

She glanced back only a moment to observe him. As a guard, skiir was required to keep himself in a better physical condition, and his training showed. THe strength in his arms and back was evident in the toned muscles under the scales, and even the tail appeared to be strong. He probably could knock any kobold in the clan down with a swipe of that.

"Enjoying the show?" Skiir grinned and slipped into the water beside her, taking some mud from the bottom of the pool and scrubbing it against Frill's back. "We will need to get you presentable for the humans. They have rather delicate sensibilities.

She settled into the feeling of the mud scrubbed into her back scales. He was spoiling her, she knew it... But every so often a kobold enjoyed being spoiled.
115211.title: Take offer of going to the Human Town. You will...

choices: Stay and see what happens. Flare is the dragon in charge of the entire clan.
1152112.content:
"Well what do we have here..." Frill and Skiir glance up in surprise as the voice was not a kobold one, but spoke draconic with a flourish that came from experience. On the other side of the pond, a red scaled kobold approached. Skiir gave an audiable gulp, and for good reason. There was no red scaled kobolds in the clan.

The kobold looked between Frill and Skiir, before waving a claw to the guard. "You are dismissed."

Skiir gulped again before speaking. "S..sssir I..."

The creature gave a glare to Skiir and hissed menacingly. "I said... dismissed." Skiir quickly ran off, grabbing his armor on the way. The red scaled kobold gave a light growl under his breath before looking back to Frill. "You kobolds get really brave at times dont you?" He grinned to her before running a claw up her neck and stared into her eyes.

Frill gulped as she looked into those eyes that glinted with an intelligence far more than what most kobolds had. "I... was unaware we had any red scaled kobolds in the clan..."

The "kobold" gave an amused look. "Surely even one as low in the ranks as you have heard of me.... The name is Flare.."

Frills eyes widened at the mention of the name. She knew who Flare was, Flare was the red dragon the kobold clan served. "F..Flare.. Sir.. What can I assist you with..." She gulped, trying to remain respectful, but she was in a dangerous position as it was.

Flare's grin widened as he could smell her fear. "I was looking for a bit of entertainment, and seems i found it." He gives a low growl as he leans forward, pressing against her and back up to the pool wall."
1152112.title: Something interrupts them.

11521123.content:
She gave a low growl as her eyes flashed. She did not care if Flare was a dragon or not. In a moment, the fear in her eyes vanished as she pushed him back. "Now you listen to me, dragon! I don't care how powerful you are, or how easy it would be for you to snap my neck here and now. I will NOT allow myself to be taken down and treated like I am a throw away toy for your entertainment."

Flares eyes just watched her as Frill stood her ground. She didnt know why she did it, it just.. felt like the right thing to do. Flare then gave a grin. "Well now, seems the little blue kobold has some backbone. Good, you are worth my time. I have need for a new assistant. The last one disappointed me." He gave a hiss as he leaned down in front of her. "I do expect you to accept, and be grateful I don't end your life now for your subordination." He snarls and snaps his teeth close to her neck.

Frill wasn't quite sure what had happened, she was certain she was about to die. The only thing she was able to muster was a nod.

"Good, glad we understand each other. But allow me to be clear.. You are of dragon blood, and that means you have a use to me, just like all others here. You are not to allow any to mate with you without my express approval, or I will kill both you, and whoever dares touch you. Do I make myself clear on this as well?"

She hissed a bit under her breath, about to say something about being told what to do, but the look on Flares face was very clear... He would not bode any disrespect. Again she nodded, choosing to keep her mouth shut.

Flare nodded. "Good lass... I knew you were an intelligent one. In time you will find yourself with more suitors than you can handle, provided they at least part dragon." He grins as he licks his lips and looks her up and down. "For now, you are to locate Chieftain Klang, and summon him to me. I have a task for him and you will be following him to assist. Do not keep me waiting."

Frill gulped and nodded, heading out of the private bathing area back to the main recreational center. Klang was over by his private pool, two kobolds at his side, and calling out for the bartender. Without missing a beat, she made his way to him.

Klang stepped out of the Jacuzzi, making himself decent before facing Frill.

"Ah yes... is there something I may do for you?" asked Klang.

12.content:
Choose your Dragon Type

Brass Dragon

At birth, a brass dragon’s scales are a dull, mottled brown. As the dragon gets older, the scales become more brassy until they reach a warm, burnished appearance. The grand head-plates of a brass dragon are smooth and metallic, and it sports bladed chin horns that grow sharper with age. Wings and frills are mottled green toward the edges, darkening with age. As the dragon grows older, its pupils fade until the eyes resemble molten metal orbs.

Brass dragons would rather talk than fight. If an intelligent creature tries to leave without engaging in conversation, the dragon might force compliance in a fit of pique, using suggestion or a dose of sleep gas. A creature put to sleep may wake to find itself pinned or buried to the neck in the sand until the dragon’s thirst for small talk is slaked. When faced with real danger, younger brass dragons fly out of sight, then hide by burrowing into the sand. Older dragons spurn this ploy but still prefer to have the advantage in combat.

Breath Weapon: A brass dragon has two types of breath weapon, a line of fire and a cone of sleep

Bronze Dragon

A bronze wyrmling’s scales are yellow tinged with green, showing only a hint of bronze. As the dragon approaches adulthood, its color deepens slowly to a darker, rich bronze tone. Very old dragons develop a blue-black tint to the edges of their scales. Powerful swimmers, they have webbed feet and smooth, flat scales. The pupils of its eyes fade as a dragon ages, until in the oldest the eyes resemble glowing green orbs.

Bronze dragons dislike killing animals and would rather bribe them (perhaps with food) or force them away magically. They use detect thoughts to learn intelligent creatures’ intentions.

When attacking they blind their opponents with fog cloud and then charge or, if flying, snatch them up. Against seafaring opponents they conjure up a storm or use their tails to smash the vessels’ hulls. If a dragon is inclined to be lenient, ships might be merely becalmed, fogbound, or broken-masted.

Breath Weapon: Bronze dragons have two types of breath weapon, a line of lightning and a cone of repulsion gas.

Copper Dragon

At birth, a copper dragon’s scales have a ruddy brown color with a metallic tint. As the dragon gets older, the scales become finer and more coppery, assuming a soft, warm gloss by young adult age. Very old dragons’ scales pick up a green tint. A copper dragon’s pupils fade with age, and the eyes of great wyrms resemble glowing turquoise orbs.

A copper dragon appreciates wit and usually doesn’t harm creatures that can relate a joke, humorous story, or riddle the dragon has not heard before. It quickly gets annoyed with anyone who doesn’t laugh at its jokes or accept its tricks with good humor. It likes to taunt and annoy opponents into giving up or acting foolishly.

An angry copper dragon prefers to mire foes using transmute rock to mud. The dragon pushes trapped opponents into the mud or snatches and carries them aloft. A copper dragon tries to draw airborne enemies into narrow, stony gorges where it can use its spider climb ability and maneuver them into colliding with the walls.

Breath Weapon: A copper dragon has two types of breath weapon, a line of acid and a cone of slow gas.

Silver Dragon

A silver wyrmling’s scales are blue-gray with silver highlights. As the dragon approaches adulthood, its color gradually brightens until the individual scales are scarcely visible.

Silver dragons are not violent and avoid combat except when faced with highly evil or aggressive foes. If necessary, they use fog cloud or control weather to blind or confuse opponents before attacking. When angry, they use reverse gravity to fling enemies helplessly into the air, where they can be snatched. Against flying opponents, a silver dragon hides in clouds (creating some with control weather on clear days), then jumps to the attack when it has the advantage.

Breath Weapon: A silver dragon has two types of breath weapon, a cone of cold and a cone of paralyzing gas

Gold Dragon

On hatching, a gold dragon’s scales are dark yellow with golden metallic flecks.

The flecks get larger as the dragon matures until, at the adult stage, the scales are completely golden. Gold dragons’ faces are bewhiskered and sagacious; as they age, their pupils fade until the eyes resemble pools of molten gold.


Gold dragons usually parley before fighting. When conversing with intelligent creatures, they use Intimidate and Sense Motive to gain the upper hand. In combat, they employ bless and their luck bonus; older dragons use their luck bonus at the start of each day. They make heavy use of spells in combat. Among their favorites are cloudkill, delayed blast fireball, fire shield, globe of invulnerability, maze, sleep, slow, and stinking cloud.

Breath Weapon: A gold dragon has two types of breath weapon, a cone of fire and a cone of weakening gas.

Choose your Dragon Type

Amethyst dragon

Breath weapon: Line of force

The most powerful of the neutral gem dragons, amethyst dragons are honorable, regal creatures. They inhabit the mountains of the northern islands, living on the shores of isolated lakes and pools. At birth, these dragons have lavender skin with fine, translucent-purple scales. These scales darken as the creature grows older, eventually reaching a sparkling lavender color.

These creatures approach life with a detached air, ignoring the conflicts of good and evil, law and chaos. At best, they see these conflicts as petty squabbles over inconsequential points of view, and not worthy of their time or consideration. These majestic dragons consider themselves to be the leaders of the gem dragons, and most of the lesser gem dragons acquiesce to this leadership. While amethyst dragons consider their silver and copper cousins to be foolish and have an active dislike of red and white dragons, they do not consider any life form to be their inherent enemies. They prefer to reason out a settlement through discussion and negotiation rather than through combat, but they can and will fight if they must. Being honourable and noble, these dragons never hide or attempt to ambush foes. To them, even retreating is a dishonourable action, but they will flee if faced with certain death. Amethyst dragons eat large quantities of fish and gems. They keep vassals to attend to their needs, though they do not place as many restrictions or requirements on them as other dragon lords do. Most keep at least one hidden, underwater cave for seclusion and secrecy. Amethyst dragons approach mating in a very logical manner, seeking the optimum partner to produce the best offspring. Love and pleasure rarely, if ever, enter the equation.

14.content:
Choose your Dragon Type

Black Dragon

Black dragon are sometimes known as skull dragons because of their skeletal faces. Adding to the skeletal impression is the gradual deterioration of the hide around the base of the horn and the cheekbones. This deterioration increases with age and does not harm the dragon. On hatching, a black dragon’s scales are thin, small, and glossy. As the dragon ages, they become larger, thicker, and duller, helping it camouflage itself in swamps and marshes.

Black dragons are especially fond of coins. Older dragons sometimes capture and question humanoids about stockpiles of gold, silver, and platinum coins before killing them.

Black dragons prefer to ambush their targets, using their surroundings as cover. When fighting in heavily forested swamps and marshes, they try to stay in the water or on the ground; trees and leafy canopies limit their aerial maneuverability. When outmatched, a black dragon attempts to fly out of sight, so as not to leave tracks, and hide in a deep pond or bog.

Breath Weapon: A black dragon has one type of breath weapon, a line of acid.

Blue Dragon

A blue dragon’s scales vary in color from an iridescent azure to a deep indigo, polished to a glossy finish by blowing desert sands. The size of its scales increases little as the dragon ages, although they do become thicker and harder. Its hide tends to hum and crackle faintly with built-up static electricity. These effects intensify when the dragon is angry or about to attack, giving off an odor of ozone and sand. Their vibrant color makes blue dragons easy to spot in barren desert surroundings. However, they often burrow into the sand so only part of their heads are exposed.

Blue dragons love to soar in the hot desert air, usually flying in the daytime when temperatures are highest. Some nearly match the color of the desert sky and use this coloration to their advantage.

Blue dragons lair in vast underground caverns, where they also store their treasure. Although they collect anything that looks valuable, they are most fond of gems—especially sapphires.

Typically, blue dragons attack from above or burrow beneath the sands until opponents come within 100 feet. Older dragons use their special abilities, such as hallucinatory terrain, in concert with these tactics to mask the land and improve their chances to surprise the target. Blue dragons run from a fight only if they are severely damaged, since they view retreat as cowardly.

Breath Weapon: A blue dragon has one type of breath weapon, a line of lightning.

Green Dragon

A wyrmling green dragon’s scales are thin, very small, and a deep shade of green that appears nearly black. As the dragon ages, the scales grow larger and lighter, turning shades of forest, emerald, and olive green, which helps it blend in with its wooded surroundings.

Green dragons initiate fights with little or no provocation, picking on creatures of any size. If the target is intriguing or seems formidable, the dragon stalks the creature to determine the best time to strike and the most appropriate tactics to use. If the target appears weak, the dragon makes its presence known quickly—it enjoys evoking terror. Sometimes the dragon elects to control a humanoid creature through intimidation and suggestion. Green dragons especially like to question adventurers to learn more about their society and abilities, what is going on in the countryside, and if there is treasure nearby.

Breath Weapon: A green dragon has one type of breath weapon, a cone of acid.

Red Dragon

The small scales of a wyrmling red dragon are a bright glossy scarlet, making the dragon easily spotted by predators and hunters, so it stays underground and does not venture outside until it is more able to take care of itself. Toward the end of young age, the scales turn a deeper red, and the glossy texture is replaced by a smooth, dull finish. As the dragon grows older, the scales become large, thick, and as strong as metal. The neck frill and wings are an ash blue or purple-gray toward the edges, becoming darker with age. The pupils of a red dragon fade as it ages; the oldest red dragons have eyes that resemble molten lava orbs.

Because red dragons are so confident, they seldom pause to appraise an adversary. On spotting a target, they make a snap decision whether to attack, using one of many strategies worked out ahead of time. A red dragon lands to attack small, weak creatures with its claws and bite rather than obliterating them with its breath weapon, so as not to destroy any treasure they might be carrying.

Breath Weapon: A red dragon has one type of breath weapon, a cone of fire.

White Dragon

The scales of a wyrmling white dragon glisten like mirrors. As the dragon ages, the sheen disappears, and by very old age, scales of pale blue and light gray are mixed in with the white.

White dragons prefer sudden assaults, swooping down from aloft or bursting from beneath water, snow, or ice. They loose their breath weapon, then try to knock out a single opponent with a follow-up attack.

Breath Weapon: A white dragon has one type of breath weapon, a cone of cold.

Choose your Dragon Type

Brass Dragon

At birth, a brass dragon’s scales are a dull, mottled brown. As the dragon gets older, the scales become more brassy until they reach a warm, burnished appearance. The grand head-plates of a brass dragon are smooth and metallic, and it sports bladed chin horns that grow sharper with age. Wings and frills are mottled green toward the edges, darkening with age. As the dragon grows older, its pupils fade until the eyes resemble molten metal orbs.

Brass dragons would rather talk than fight. If an intelligent creature tries to leave without engaging in conversation, the dragon might force compliance in a fit of pique, using suggestion or a dose of sleep gas. A creature put to sleep may wake to find itself pinned or buried to the neck in the sand until the dragon’s thirst for small talk is slaked. When faced with real danger, younger brass dragons fly out of sight, then hide by burrowing into the sand. Older dragons spurn this ploy but still prefer to have the advantage in combat.

Breath Weapon: A brass dragon has two types of breath weapon, a line of fire and a cone of sleep

Bronze Dragon

A bronze wyrmling’s scales are yellow tinged with green, showing only a hint of bronze. As the dragon approaches adulthood, its color deepens slowly to a darker, rich bronze tone. Very old dragons develop a blue-black tint to the edges of their scales. Powerful swimmers, they have webbed feet and smooth, flat scales. The pupils of its eyes fade as a dragon ages, until in the oldest the eyes resemble glowing green orbs.

Bronze dragons dislike killing animals and would rather bribe them (perhaps with food) or force them away magically. They use detect thoughts to learn intelligent creatures’ intentions.

When attacking they blind their opponents with fog cloud and then charge or, if flying, snatch them up. Against seafaring opponents they conjure up a storm or use their tails to smash the vessels’ hulls. If a dragon is inclined to be lenient, ships might be merely becalmed, fogbound, or broken-masted.

Breath Weapon: Bronze dragons have two types of breath weapon, a line of lightning and a cone of repulsion gas.

Copper Dragon

At birth, a copper dragon’s scales have a ruddy brown color with a metallic tint. As the dragon gets older, the scales become finer and more coppery, assuming a soft, warm gloss by young adult age. Very old dragons’ scales pick up a green tint. A copper dragon’s pupils fade with age, and the eyes of great wyrms resemble glowing turquoise orbs.

A copper dragon appreciates wit and usually doesn’t harm creatures that can relate a joke, humorous story, or riddle the dragon has not heard before. It quickly gets annoyed with anyone who doesn’t laugh at its jokes or accept its tricks with good humor. It likes to taunt and annoy opponents into giving up or acting foolishly.

An angry copper dragon prefers to mire foes using transmute rock to mud. The dragon pushes trapped opponents into the mud or snatches and carries them aloft. A copper dragon tries to draw airborne enemies into narrow, stony gorges where it can use its spider climb ability and maneuver them into colliding with the walls.

Breath Weapon: A copper dragon has two types of breath weapon, a line of acid and a cone of slow gas.

Silver Dragon

A silver wyrmling’s scales are blue-gray with silver highlights. As the dragon approaches adulthood, its color gradually brightens until the individual scales are scarcely visible.

Silver dragons are not violent and avoid combat except when faced with highly evil or aggressive foes. If necessary, they use fog cloud or control weather to blind or confuse opponents before attacking. When angry, they use reverse gravity to fling enemies helplessly into the air, where they can be snatched. Against flying opponents, a silver dragon hides in clouds (creating some with control weather on clear days), then jumps to the attack when it has the advantage.

Breath Weapon: A silver dragon has two types of breath weapon, a cone of cold and a cone of paralyzing gas

Gold Dragon

On hatching, a gold dragon’s scales are dark yellow with golden metallic flecks.

The flecks get larger as the dragon matures until, at the adult stage, the scales are completely golden. Gold dragons’ faces are bewhiskered and sagacious; as they age, their pupils fade until the eyes resemble pools of molten gold.


Gold dragons usually parley before fighting. When conversing with intelligent creatures, they use Intimidate and Sense Motive to gain the upper hand. In combat, they employ bless and their luck bonus; older dragons use their luck bonus at the start of each day. They make heavy use of spells in combat. Among their favorites are cloudkill, delayed blast fireball, fire shield, globe of invulnerability, maze, sleep, slow, and stinking cloud.

Breath Weapon: A gold dragon has two types of breath weapon, a cone of fire and a cone of weakening gas.

Black dragons prefer to ambush their targets, using their surroundings as cover. When fighting in heavily forested swamps and marshes, they try to stay in the water or on the ground; trees and leafy canopies limit their aerial maneuverability. When outmatched, a black dragon attempts to fly out of sight, so as not to leave tracks, and hide in a deep pond or bog.

Breath Weapon: A black dragon has one type of breath weapon, a line of acid.

Blue Dragon

A blue dragon’s scales vary in color from an iridescent azure to a deep indigo, polished to a glossy finish by blowing desert sands. The size of its scales increases little as the dragon ages, although they do become thicker and harder. Its hide tends to hum and crackle faintly with built-up static electricity. These effects intensify when the dragon is angry or about to attack, giving off an odor of ozone and sand. Their vibrant color makes blue dragons easy to spot in barren desert surroundings. However, they often burrow into the sand so only part of their heads are exposed.

Blue dragons love to soar in the hot desert air, usually flying in the daytime when temperatures are highest. Some nearly match the color of the desert sky and use this coloration to their advantage.

Blue dragons lair in vast underground caverns, where they also store their treasure. Although they collect anything that looks valuable, they are most fond of gems—especially sapphires.

Typically, blue dragons attack from above or burrow beneath the sands until opponents come within 100 feet. Older dragons use their special abilities, such as hallucinatory terrain, in concert with these tactics to mask the land and improve their chances to surprise the target. Blue dragons run from a fight only if they are severely damaged, since they view retreat as cowardly.

Breath Weapon: A blue dragon has one type of breath weapon, a line of lightning.

Green Dragon

A wyrmling green dragon’s scales are thin, very small, and a deep shade of green that appears nearly black. As the dragon ages, the scales grow larger and lighter, turning shades of forest, emerald, and olive green, which helps it blend in with its wooded surroundings.

Green dragons initiate fights with little or no provocation, picking on creatures of any size. If the target is intriguing or seems formidable, the dragon stalks the creature to determine the best time to strike and the most appropriate tactics to use. If the target appears weak, the dragon makes its presence known quickly—it enjoys evoking terror. Sometimes the dragon elects to control a humanoid creature through intimidation and suggestion. Green dragons especially like to question adventurers to learn more about their society and abilities, what is going on in the countryside, and if there is treasure nearby.

Breath Weapon: A green dragon has one type of breath weapon, a cone of acid.

Red Dragon

The small scales of a wyrmling red dragon are a bright glossy scarlet, making the dragon easily spotted by predators and hunters, so it stays underground and does not venture outside until it is more able to take care of itself. Toward the end of young age, the scales turn a deeper red, and the glossy texture is replaced by a smooth, dull finish. As the dragon grows older, the scales become large, thick, and as strong as metal. The neck frill and wings are an ash blue or purple-gray toward the edges, becoming darker with age. The pupils of a red dragon fade as it ages; the oldest red dragons have eyes that resemble molten lava orbs.

Because red dragons are so confident, they seldom pause to appraise an adversary. On spotting a target, they make a snap decision whether to attack, using one of many strategies worked out ahead of time. A red dragon lands to attack small, weak creatures with its claws and bite rather than obliterating them with its breath weapon, so as not to destroy any treasure they might be carrying.

Breath Weapon: A red dragon has one type of breath weapon, a cone of fire.

White Dragon

The scales of a wyrmling white dragon glisten like mirrors. As the dragon ages, the sheen disappears, and by very old age, scales of pale blue and light gray are mixed in with the white.

White dragons prefer sudden assaults, swooping down from aloft or bursting from beneath water, snow, or ice. They loose their breath weapon, then try to knock out a single opponent with a follow-up attack.

Breath Weapon: A white dragon has one type of breath weapon, a cone of cold.

Brass Dragon

At birth, a brass dragon’s scales are a dull, mottled brown. As the dragon gets older, the scales become more brassy until they reach a warm, burnished appearance. The grand head-plates of a brass dragon are smooth and metallic, and it sports bladed chin horns that grow sharper with age. Wings and frills are mottled green toward the edges, darkening with age. As the dragon grows older, its pupils fade until the eyes resemble molten metal orbs.

Brass dragons would rather talk than fight. If an intelligent creature tries to leave without engaging in conversation, the dragon might force compliance in a fit of pique, using suggestion or a dose of sleep gas. A creature put to sleep may wake to find itself pinned or buried to the neck in the sand until the dragon’s thirst for small talk is slaked. When faced with real danger, younger brass dragons fly out of sight, then hide by burrowing into the sand. Older dragons spurn this ploy but still prefer to have the advantage in combat.

Breath Weapon: A brass dragon has two types of breath weapon, a line of fire and a cone of sleep

Bronze Dragon

A bronze wyrmling’s scales are yellow tinged with green, showing only a hint of bronze. As the dragon approaches adulthood, its color deepens slowly to a darker, rich bronze tone. Very old dragons develop a blue-black tint to the edges of their scales. Powerful swimmers, they have webbed feet and smooth, flat scales. The pupils of its eyes fade as a dragon ages, until in the oldest the eyes resemble glowing green orbs.

Bronze dragons dislike killing animals and would rather bribe them (perhaps with food) or force them away magically. They use detect thoughts to learn intelligent creatures’ intentions.

When attacking they blind their opponents with fog cloud and then charge or, if flying, snatch them up. Against seafaring opponents they conjure up a storm or use their tails to smash the vessels’ hulls. If a dragon is inclined to be lenient, ships might be merely becalmed, fogbound, or broken-masted.

Breath Weapon: Bronze dragons have two types of breath weapon, a line of lightning and a cone of repulsion gas.

Copper Dragon

At birth, a copper dragon’s scales have a ruddy brown color with a metallic tint. As the dragon gets older, the scales become finer and more coppery, assuming a soft, warm gloss by young adult age. Very old dragons’ scales pick up a green tint. A copper dragon’s pupils fade with age, and the eyes of great wyrms resemble glowing turquoise orbs.

A copper dragon appreciates wit and usually doesn’t harm creatures that can relate a joke, humorous story, or riddle the dragon has not heard before. It quickly gets annoyed with anyone who doesn’t laugh at its jokes or accept its tricks with good humor. It likes to taunt and annoy opponents into giving up or acting foolishly.

An angry copper dragon prefers to mire foes using transmute rock to mud. The dragon pushes trapped opponents into the mud or snatches and carries them aloft. A copper dragon tries to draw airborne enemies into narrow, stony gorges where it can use its spider climb ability and maneuver them into colliding with the walls.

Breath Weapon: A copper dragon has two types of breath weapon, a line of acid and a cone of slow gas.

Silver Dragon

A silver wyrmling’s scales are blue-gray with silver highlights. As the dragon approaches adulthood, its color gradually brightens until the individual scales are scarcely visible.

Silver dragons are not violent and avoid combat except when faced with highly evil or aggressive foes. If necessary, they use fog cloud or control weather to blind or confuse opponents before attacking. When angry, they use reverse gravity to fling enemies helplessly into the air, where they can be snatched. Against flying opponents, a silver dragon hides in clouds (creating some with control weather on clear days), then jumps to the attack when it has the advantage.

Breath Weapon: A silver dragon has two types of breath weapon, a cone of cold and a cone of paralyzing gas

Gold Dragon

On hatching, a gold dragon’s scales are dark yellow with golden metallic flecks.

The flecks get larger as the dragon matures until, at the adult stage, the scales are completely golden. Gold dragons’ faces are bewhiskered and sagacious; as they age, their pupils fade until the eyes resemble pools of molten gold.


Gold dragons usually parley before fighting. When conversing with intelligent creatures, they use Intimidate and Sense Motive to gain the upper hand. In combat, they employ bless and their luck bonus; older dragons use their luck bonus at the start of each day. They make heavy use of spells in combat. Among their favorites are cloudkill, delayed blast fireball, fire shield, globe of invulnerability, maze, sleep, slow, and stinking cloud.

Breath Weapon: A gold dragon has two types of breath weapon, a cone of fire and a cone of weakening gas.
